column1:
06/01/17 12:18 PM EDT|"7 Must-Read Books For Your Summer Reading List"|""|""|""|"

For your reading pleasure
column2: below is a list of books that come highly-recommended by our CEO Keith McCullough across a variety of topics
column3:
from markets to behavioral economics and leadership.

Enjoy!

On Markets...

1. THE MISBEHAVIOR OF MARKETS: A FRACTAL VIEW OF FINANCIAL TURBULENCE

by Benoit Mandelbrot
column4: Richard L. Hudson
column8:
//d1yhils6iwh5l5.cloudfront.net/charts/resized/48215/large/mandel.png 900w" />

Amazon: "Mathematical superstar and inventor of fractal geometry
column10:
has spent the past forty years studying the underlying mathematics of space and natural patterns. What many of his followers don't realize is that he has also been watching patterns of market change."

Hedgeye CEO Keith McCullough: "This is one of the best books about markets I’ve ever read. In investing more broadly and macro specifically
column11:
the multiple factors we have to consider across multiple durations is considerably large. That’s why I’m such a big fan of Mandelbrot. The mother of all encompassing concepts is fractal geometry. It knows no bounds. It abhors the consensus path of linearity and it embraces the uncertainty of our ever-changing ecosystem. I love that."



2. How Not to Be Wrong: The Power of Mathematical Thinking

by Jordan Ellenberg
column15:
//d1yhils6iwh5l5.cloudfront.net/charts/resized/48215/large/ellenberg.png 900w" />

Amazon: "The Freakonomics of math—a math-world superstar unveils the hidden beauty and logic of the world and puts its power in our hands. How Not to Be Wrong presents the surprising revelations behind all of these questions and many more
column16:
using the mathematician’s method of analyzing life and exposing the hard-won insights of the academic community to the layman—minus the jargon."

McCullough: "If you’re looking to improve your decision making process (i.e. improving your ability to change your mind
column19: read Ellenberg’s book. I can’t stress how important using a rigorous
column21:
Bayesian overlay is to our process."



3. Adaptive Markets: Financial Evolution at the Speed of Thought

by Andrew W. Lo
column25:
//d1yhils6iwh5l5.cloudfront.net/charts/resized/48215/large/lo_mkts.png 900w" />

Amazon: "A fascinating intellectual journey filled with compelling stories
column26: Adaptive Markets starts with the origins of market efficiency and its failures
column27: turns to the foundations of investor behavior
column28: and concludes with practical implications--including how hedge funds have become the Galápagos Islands of finance
column29: what really happened in the 2008 meltdown
column30:
and how we might avoid future crises."

Hedgeye Senior Macro Analyst Darius Dale: "The overarching message of Lo’s book
column31: from the introduction to the chapter I couldn’t wait to skip ahead to roughly 300 pages later
column32: is that an overreliance on either classical economics and complex financial models (e.g. Fama’s Efficient Market Hypothesis
column33: Black-Scholes-Merton Model) has led to misguided views among investors
column34:
academics and policymakers about how financial markets actually work."

On Behavioral Economics
column35:
Investor Psychology...  

4. Messy: The Power of Disorder to Transform Our Lives

by Tim Harford
column39:
//d1yhils6iwh5l5.cloudfront.net/charts/resized/48215/large/messy.png 900w" />

Amazon: "For those who think that a spick-and-span desk is an indication of high productivity
column40:
Harford's fascinating investigation of how disorder can spark innovation will open your eyes to all kinds of situations when tidiness is not a virtue."

McCullough: "In Tim Harford's book Messy
column41:
he discusses the dangers of shutting your mind to new ideas:

'The idea is to keep opening up new conversational possibilities rather than shut them down... [otherwise] the pattern repeats endlessly. We gain new choices about whom to listen to
column43:
and whom to befriend – and we use those choices to tighten the circle around us to people who are more and more like us.' 

I humbly suggest that you don’t do that. For market practitioners
column44:
having the mental flexibility to change your mind is critical."



5. Hooked: How to Build Habit-Forming Products

by Nir Eyal
column48:
//d1yhils6iwh5l5.cloudfront.net/charts/resized/48215/large/hooked.png 900w" />

Amazon: "Why do some products capture widespread attention while others flop? What makes us engage with certain products out of sheer habit? Is there a pattern underlying how technologies hook us? Nir Eyal answers these questions (and many more) by explaining the Hook Model—a four-step process embedded into the products of many successful companies to subtly encourage customer behavior."

McCullough: "At a recent Hedgeye offsite meeting
column49:
I focused our senior leadership team on some of the learnings from Nir Eyal’s Hooked book that I’ve cited in recent Early Looks. One of the behavioral models he considers is the Fogg Behavior Model. The formula for Fogg is B = MAT: 

“... which represents that a given behavior will occur when motivation (M)
column51: and a trigger (T) are present at the same time… Fogg states that all humans are motivated to seek pleasure and avoid pain; to seek hope and avoid fear; and finally
column52:
to seek social acceptance and avoid rejection.” 

Sound familiar? The polarizing
column54: and political media is perpetually trying to tap into our predictable behavior. As you glance or glare at the latest Trump headlines this morning
column55:
I encourage you to emphasize repeatable investment #process over politics."

On Leadership...

6. American Ulysses: A Life of Ulysses S. Grant

by Ronald C. White
column60: Ulysses S. Grant was routinely grouped with George Washington and Abraham Lincoln in the “Trinity of Great American Leaders.” But the battlefield commander–turned–commander-in-chief fell out of favor in the twentieth century. In <i>American Ulysses
column61:
Ronald C. White argues that we need to once more revise our estimates of him in the twenty-first."

McCullough: "If you’re into having an ongoing education about US History (published in 2016)
column62:
I highly recommend this book. It’s decorated with leadership lessons in American life. As Grant said:

'Our business here is prosperous and I have every reason to hope to be entirely above the frowns of the world.' In our profession
column63:
the frowns of the world are manifest.'

For the last 9 years I’ve thought that was a tremendous opportunity and I've built my business around that. There’s a better way. In fact there’s a way better way. So let’s embrace that opportunity."



7. Mandela's Way: Lessons on Life
column65:
and Courage

by Richard Stengel
column70: profoundly inspiring book that captures the spirit of Nelson Mandela
column71:
distilling the South African leader’s wisdom into 15 vital life lessons."


McCullough: "I don’t think the opportunity to lead in this business has ever been better. As Mandela taught many
column72: that doesn’t always mean leading from the front. Sometimes the opportunity to “lead from the back” of a movement is as powerful as any: “The way to do that is by empowering or pushing others to move forward ahead of you.” Autobiographer
column74:
asked Mandela how prison changed him.

“How was the man who came out in 1990 different from the man who entered in 1962? Emotional? Passionate? Sensitive? Quickly Stung? The Nelson Mandela who emerged from prison is none of those things… time and again the words I heard him use to praise others were balanced
column76:
and controlled."

When it comes to running your (or other people’s) money
column77: how would you describe yourself? I know how I used to be. And it was me
column78:
but it was not good. Playing this game with the emotion I had on the ice didn’t work. Becoming measured did."

"

column1:
06/01/17 08:55 AM EDT|"Hedgeye Announces Opening of New Office In Washington D.C."|""|""|""|"

Investment research firm continues its expansion as 10-year anniversary approaches

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

WASHINGTON D.C.
column5: the independent provider of investment research and online financial media firm
column6: announced today that it has officially opened its new Washington D.C office located in the heart of the nation’s capital. The firm’s expansion follows its acquisition of Potomac Research Group—an independent research firm which provides predictive Washington policy analysis to institutional investors—in January of 2016.
column10:
//d1yhils6iwh5l5.cloudfront.net/charts/resized/48208/large/zw7.jpg 900w" />

“We are very excited about this new phase in our firm’s evolution
column11: ” said Hedgeye Founder and CEO Keith McCullough. “Our new office is in the heart of D.C.—a short walk from the White House
column13: embassies and think tanks. This was the next logical step in our firm’s growth trajectory
column14:
particularly in light of the outsized role Washington policy continues to have on global markets.”

The new D.C office located at 1130 Connecticut Ave NW will be headquarters for Hedgeye Potomac analysts including Lt. Gen Emerson “Emo” Gardner
column16:
Ret. (Aerospace & Defense); JT Taylor (Domestic Policy Analysis); Joe McMonigle (Energy); Paul Glenchur (Telecom & Media); Emily Evans (Healthcare Policy) and Neil Howe (Demography).

The office also features a media studio similar to the firm’s original HedgeyeTV studio in its global headquarters in Stamford
column17:
CT.

Hedgeye currently has offices in Boston
column21:
California.

“We’re obviously thrilled about this new stage of our development
column22:
” said JT Taylor. “We‘ve assembled a deep bench of world-class policy analysts. Our team looks forward to giving investors an edge in our ‘Washington to Wall Street’ research for many years to come."

Hedgeye Potomac’s policy analysts are widely-recognized by the industry as leading authorities in their respective fields. Their unique
column23: non-consensus evaluation of federal legislative activities and regulatory and Federal Reserve policies is focused on determining Washington’s impact on highly-regulated industry sectors
column27:
technology and telecommunications.

ABOUT HEDGEYE RISK MANAGEMENT

Hedgeye Risk Management is an independent investment research and online financial media firm. Focused exclusively on generating and delivering investment ideas in a proven buy-side process
column29:
bottom-up and macro analysis with an emphasis on timing.

The Hedgeye team features some of the world's most regarded research analysts
column44:
Technology and Washington policy analysis.

*  *  *

CONTACT: Dan Holland
dholland@hedgeye.com
203.562.6500

"

column1: 06/01/17 07:56 AM EDT|"Why Wall Street Is (Really) Wrong on the U.S. Economy"|""|""|""|"
column5:
//d1yhils6iwh5l5.cloudfront.net/charts/resized/48206/large/wallst_image.png 900w">

The consensus among Wall Street money managers is that U.S. economic growth is slowing. How else could you explain big banks and hedge funds piling into the 10-year Treasury bond? That's right
column6: Wall Street's net long position in 10-year U.S. Treasuries has swollen to levels not seen in quite a while
column7:
at least since 2015. 

That's problematic because U.S. growth is accelerating. 

As you can see in the Chart of the Day below
column9: institutional investors are now net long 10-year U.S. Treasuries by 365
column11: according to CFTC futures and options data. That's quite a swing – of more than 600
column12:
000 contracts – since being net short back as recent as March.

In other words
column13: institutional investors are betting that the U.S. economy is poised for a tumble
column14:
since bonds typically rally when economic growth slows. Here's analysis from Hedgeye CEO Keith McCullough:

"Since Consensus Macro is as long of #GrowthSlowing as it has been in 2017 (there’s a non-commercial net LONG position in the 10yr Treasury Bond of +365
column15: 011 contracts as of last week which registers +2.06x on a 1-year z-score)
column16: when will that consensus capitulate into being long real #GrowthAccelerating?"
column20:
//d1yhils6iwh5l5.cloudfront.net/charts/resized/48206/large/06.01.17_Chart.png 900w">

THE U.S. ECONOMY: HEDGEYE VERSUS WALL STREET

To be clear
column21: our call is the complete opposite side of Wall Street's trade. The U.S. economy is accelerating. Consider the facts. Year-over-year GDP growth peaked at 3.3% in the first quarter 2015
column22: fell to 1.3% by the second quarter of 2016
column23:
and has since rebounded to 2% for the first quarter of 2017. 

We expect rebounding U.S. growth to continually surprise Wall Street consensus throughout 2017.
column27:
//d1yhils6iwh5l5.cloudfront.net/charts/resized/48206/large/gdp_yoy.png 900w">

IT'S WORTH NOTING... 

To close the month of May
column28:
the S&P 500 sectors reflect a growing U.S. economy. Here are the leaders year-to-date:

  • Technology (XLK): +16.7%
  • Consumer Discretionary (XLY): +11.9%

Think about it. Tech and Consumer Discretionary stocks should outperform as growth accelerates since these are the sectors that are tethered to U.S. consumer spending.
